title-group.article-title: Dropping damage evaluation for a hyperbolic tangent cushioning system with a critical component

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Packaging Engineering, Jiangnan University, Wuxi, People's Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Jun Wang, Department of Packaging Engineering, Jiangnan University, Wuxi 214122, People’s Republic of China Email: packei@yahoo.com.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A new concept of dropping damage boundary surface is proposed to evaluate the dropping damage of a critical component for a hyperbolic tangent nonlinear packaging system. A novel dynamic model is established to analyze the effect of three key coordinate parameters, i.e., the non-dimensional dropping shock velocity, the frequency parameter ratio and the defined system parameter, on dropping damage potential. An experiment, which showed good agreement, was conducted to verify the theory proposed.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Since Newton (1968) suggested the classical damage boundary concept, much effort has been made in the special field of packaging dynamics. Some researchers have expressed much interest in the dynamic properties of cushioning materials (White et al., 2010; Zhang and Dupuis, 2011). While others devoted themselves to the damage mechanism for cushioned products, and some modified damage evaluation approaches for linear and nonlinear packaging systems were proposed in the past few years (Burgess, 1988; Wang and Hu, 1999; Wang et al., 1998). These works discussed the product fragility under the action of different kinds of acceleration pulse. However, the damage of most packaged products is caused by dropping shock during the transport process. Therefore, it is very important to develop a method for evaluating the dropping damage of packaged products. Wang (2002) proposed a dropping damage boundary concept for linear and nonlinear packaging systems. Those traditional damage evaluation approaches may not be suitable in some cases when the packaged products are damaged with possible failures or faults in a critical component (Wang and Wang, 2011). For this reason, the concepts of a three-dimensional shock response spectrum and damage boundary surface were developed to evaluate the damage potential of shocks to critical components for different nonlinear packaging systems (Wang and Wang, 2008; Wang et al., 2010; 2011).

In this paper, the dropping shock dynamics of a hyperbolic tangent system is discussed, and a concept of dropping damage boundary surface (DDBS) is developed to evaluate the dropping damage of the critical component.

sec.title: 2. Modeling and equations
sec.p: Many cushion materials, such as honeycomb paperboard, corrugated paperboard and foam plastics, have an approximately hyperbolic tangent force-displacement relation in a certain deformation range. The corresponding restoring force for a hyperbolic tangent system can be expressed as: (1)f(x0)=F0thk0x0F0. where F0 is the limiting value of the restoring force.

The model for a hyperbolic tangent packaging system with a critical component can be described as in Figure 1, in which the packaging is idealized as a nonlinear spring with an initial stiffness coefficient of k2. The joint part between the critical component (m1) and the main body of product (m2) is idealized as a linear spring with a stiffness coefficient of k1. Figure 1.
Dynamic model for a packaging system with a critical component.

The motion of the system is governed by Figure 4 (2)m1x··1+k1(x1-x2)=0m2x··2+F0th(k2x2F0)-k1(x1-x2)=0 x1|t=0= x2|t=0=0 x·1|t=0= x·2|t=0=V0=2gH where x1 and x2 are respectively the displacement response of the critical component and the main body of the product, g is the gravity acceleration, H is the dropping height of the packaging system, and V0 is the dropping shock velocity of the product.

To simplify these equations, some new non-dimensional variables are introduced as: Xi=xi/L, τ=t/T, where T=m2/k2, L=F0/k2. Furthermore, frequency parameters of the critical component and the main body are defined as: ω1=k1/m1, ω2=k2/m2, respectively. And then, the frequency parameter ratio and mass ratio can be defined as: λ1=ω1/ω2, λ2=m1/m2.

Substituting all parameters defined above into equation (2) yields the non-dimensional form of the motion equations (3)X1 ″+λ1 2(X1-X2)=0X2 ″+thX2-λ1 2λ2(X1-X2)=0X1|t=0=X2|t=0=0 X1 '|t=0= X2 '|t=0=V=TLV0

The numerical solution to equation (3) can be obtained by applying the Runge-Kutta method, then the shock responses of the packaging system can be obtained as (4)x··i=LT2Xi ″=βXi ″(i=1,2) where β is defined as the system parameter, and the system parameter of a hyperbolic tangent nonlinear packaging system can be written as (5)β=F0/m2

sec.title: 3. Product dropping damage evaluation of critical component
sec.p: As shown in equations (3) and (4), the shock responses of the packaging system are only related to three coordinate parameters, i.e., the non-dimensional dropping shock velocity, the frequency parameter ratio and the mass ratio. As studied in our previous work, the influence of the mass ratio on the dropping shock response of the critical component is limited. Therefore, the maximum acceleration response of critical component x··1om is only related to the non-dimensional dropping shock velocity, the frequency parameter ratio and the defined system parameter. If we define Ac as the fragility of the critical component, it is obvious that the critical component will be damaged when (6)x··1om≥Acg

And the dropping damage boundary can be evaluated by three basic evaluation quantities, the dropping shock velocity, the frequency parameter ratio and the defined system parameter. The DDBS for a packaging system with a critical component can be described as in Figure 2. The critical component will be damaged when the coordinate point (λ1, V, β) enters the damaged area. Figure 2.
Dropping damage boundary surface.

Figure 3 shows the DDBSs for a hyperbolic tangent packaging system with different critical component fragilty (Ac). It is obvious that the damaged area of the critical component can be effectively reduced through increasing the fragility. The effect of the proposed three basic evaluation quantities, i.e., the non-dimensional dropping shock velocity, the frequency parameter ratio and the defined system parameter, on the damage potential of the critical component is noticeable. The critical component tends to be damaged more easily with the increase of the non-dimensional dropping shock velocity. It should be emphasized that V is related not only to the dropping height of the packaging system, but also to the system parameters integration. We can also see from Figure 3 that the damaged area of the critical component increases first and decreases afterwards with the rise of the frequency parameter ratio. The damaged area increases indefinitely when the frequency parameter ratio approaches unity, implying that there exists some dangerous area for frequency parameter ratio which should be avoided in the packaging design process. The defined system parameter also has a strong influence on the dropping damage potential of the critical component. As shown in Figure 3, the critical component can be damaged more easily with a higher value of β, implying that the critical component can be better protected by applying a cushioning pad with lower limiting value of the restoring force. Figure 3.
Dropping damage boundary surface of critical component for a hyperbolic tangent packaging system. Here, λ2 = 0.1.

sec.title: 4. Experiments
sec.p:
Experiments are carried out to verify the method proposed above on the shock machine (DY-300-3/SC-0505 A, Suzhou, China) with an experimental model for a hyperbolic tangent packaging system. This model contains three main parts: two steel disks representing the critical component with a mass of 0.603 kg and the packaged product with a mass of 3.010 kg, respectively, several springs representing the joint parts between the critical component and packaged product and several pre-compressed expanded polyethylene pads. The expanded polyethylene pad is compressed, and the load-deformation curve can be fitted by a hyperbolic tangent function, then the initial stiffness coefficient and the limiting value of the restoring force can be obtained. Several groups of the three evaluation quantities proposed above are obtained by varying combinations of joint springs and pre-compressed expanded polyethylene pads. And the peak response acceleration of the upper steel disk (critical component) is collected for each combination, which is used to predict the dropping damage boundary for the system. Finally, the measured damage boundary is compared with the predicted one, showing good agreement as in Figure 5. The results indicate that the proposed method is applicable to an actual packaging system. Figure 4.
Experimental model. Figure 5.
Experimental validation of dropping damage boundary surface.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: This work suggested a new concept of DDBS to evaluate the dropping damage for a nonlinear packaging system with a critical component, and the effect of three key coordinate parameters, i.e., the non-dimensional dropping shock velocity, the frequency parameter ratio and the defined system parameter, on dropping damage potential was analyzed by a novel dynamic model.

The frequency parameter ratio was found to have a strong influence on the damage potential of a critical component, the damaged area of the critical component increases first and decreases afterwards with the rise of the frequency parameter ratio, and the damaged area increases indefinitely when the frequency parameter ratio approaches unity, implying that there exists some dangerous area for frequency parameter ratio which should be avoided. This probably means that the inner resonance happens.

In hyperbolic tangent nonlinear packaging system, the non-dimensional dropping shock velocity is related not only to the dropping height of the packaging system but also the system parameters integration. If we treated the dynamic model as two independent single degree-of-freedom models as shown in Figure 6, the natural frequency of the main body (without damping) can be easily obtained as (7)ω2=k2/m2 Figure 6.
Two independent single degree-of-freedom models for hyperbolic packaging system with critical component.
The maximum response acceleration for m2 can be easily obtained as (8)x··2om=ω2V0
Since the limiting value of the restoring force is F0, there is also a limiting value for the maximum response acceleration of hyperbolic packaging system which can be written as (9)x··2m=F0/m2
Then the non-dimensional dropping shock velocity can be obtained as (10)V=x··2om/x··2m

It can be easily concluded from equation (10) that the dropping shock response of the main body increases with the increase of V, and then the maximum acceleration response of the critical component increases. Consequently, the critical component tends to be damaged more easily with a higher value of non-dimensional dropping shock velocity.
Moreover, substituting equation (10) into equation (8) yields (11)V0=βV/ω2
Equation (11) implies that the critical component can be damaged more easily with a higher value of β.

sec.title: Authors’ note
sec.p: Fang Duan and Jun Wang contributed equally to this work as co-first authors. Fang Duan is responsible for the experiment and analysis, and Jun Wang is responsible for the mathematical calculation and simulation.
